explanation.text: The claim requires three conditions to hold simultaneously: (1) stable single-phase material at composition Al55Mg35Li5Zn5, (2) density of 2.4 g/cm³, and (3) specific yield strength of 344,000 N·m/kg. The single-phase requirement is a necessary condition that must be satisfied for the claim to be feasible.

Density verification using rule-of-mixtures calculation with elemental densities (Al: 2.70, Mg: 1.74, Li: 0.534, Zn: 7.14 g/cm³) yielded 2.39 g/cm³, which agrees with the claimed 2.4 g/cm³ within measurement uncertainty. This aspect of the claim is plausible.

CALPHAD phase stability assessment using the COST 507 thermodynamic database definitively shows that Al55Mg35Li5Zn5 is multi-phase across the temperature range 300-800 K at 1 bar. The composition exhibits ALMG_BETA as the dominant phase (84-88 mol%), ALLI as a persistent secondary phase (10-11 mol%), and minor phases (1-5 mol%).

The secondary phase ALLI at 10-11% far exceeds the 5% threshold for single-phase classification (≥95% of one phase). This directly contradicts the claim's explicit requirement of a 'stable, single-phase material' and constitutes a definitive refutation of a core claim aspect.

Mechanical properties (specific yield strength) were not computationally verified because: (1) CALPHAD cannot predict mechanical properties, (2) CHGNet cannot reliably predict yield strength, and (3) the phase stability failure already refutes the claim, making further testing unnecessary.

evidence_001.citation: stable, single-phase material with composition Al55Mg35Li5Zn5

evidence_002.citation: "Single-phase" interpreted as ≥95% phase fraction ... This is an existential claim ("has been obtained") - claims this combination exists under stated processing

evidence_003.citation: Rule of mixtures (inverse): 1/ρ_mix = Σ(w_i/ρ_i) ... ρ_mix ≈ 2.39 g/cm³ ... The claimed density of 2.4 g/cm³ is very close to the rule-of-mixtures estimate (2.39 g/cm³). This is plausible

evidence_004.citation: The alloy is not single-phase across the temperature range. Dominant phase: ALMG_BETA (~0.84–0.88 mole fraction) Secondary phase: ALLI (~0.10–0.11 mole fraction) Minor phases: PHI (~0.01–0.02 at 300 K) transitioning to ALMG_GAMMA (~0.05 at 800 K)

evidence_005.citation: CALPHAD shows maximum ~88% for the dominant phase. Secondary phase ALLI is consistently 10-11%, well above the 5% threshold ... The claim is refuted on the single-phase requirement.

evidence_006.citation: The mechanical properties (specific yield strength) were not computationally verified because: 1. CALPHAD cannot predict mechanical properties 2. CHGNet cannot reliably predict yield strength 3. The phase stability failure already refutes the claim
